awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: The effects of Dzyaloshinskii Moriya interactions on magnetization dynamics in layered thin films
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
This project focuses on the study of the interactions that can arise at the boundary between ferromagnetic and non-magnetic materials. This interaction is key to the formation of magnetic structures that have potential as a new means to store and transmit information, and it also leads to unusual modifications of the properties of magnetic materials, important for future devices. The research teams at Bryn Mawr College and Colorado State University are taking a collaborative approach to study magnetic interactions and magnetization dynamics in order to gain new insight into the underlying physics of the interaction effects. Education for the young generation is an important component of this project. The PIs strive to involve and train students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, especially women and students from underrepresented minority groups. The students working on this project also have the opportunity to collaborate with scientists at Argonne National Laboratory and gain hands on imaging experience. The PIs incorporate research examples from this project into teaching and outreach activities at both institutions. 

Technical Abstract:
Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions (DMI) that lead to anisotropic exchange effects are rapidly gaining attention in magnetism and spintronics-related research. DMI, which arise from broken inversion symmetry and spin-orbit coupling, can occur in bulk chiral crystals and at non-magnetic/magnetic interfaces if the non-magnetic layer exhibits high spin orbit coupling. DMI promote the formation of stable chiral magnetic spin configurations such as skyrmions, and significantly modify dynamic processes in thin film systems. It has been shown that DMI can influence skyrmion and domain wall motion and that DMI lead to a nonreciprocity for surface spin waves in extended thin films. DMI should also significantly modify the dynamics in patterned magnetic nanostructures where the wavelengths of the spin dynamics are inherently short due to geometric confinement effects. In this collaborative research project, the research teams are investigating the effects of interfacial DMI on skyrmion formation and on spin dynamics in both extended and patterned multilayered films. Multilayers provide a means to stabilize submicron-sized skyrmions at room temperature by tuning not only DMI and surface anisotropies through the choice of the materials, but also the magnetostatic interactions through varying the number of repeats. The results of this project lead to new information on interfacial DMI and the effects of DMI on skyrmion formation and spin dynamics in confined geometries.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to investigate the effects of Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions (DMIs) in multilayered magnetic/heavy metal thin films, with a strong focus on magnetic skyrmions, small topologically protected swirling spin textures. Multilayered materials with interfacial DMIs have enabled the formation of stable skyrmions at room temperature, which have potential for a wide range of device applications with low energy consumption, including memory, microwave oscillators, logic devices, etc. In this collaborative project, the Buchanan group from Colorado State University (CSU) and the Cheng group from Bryn Maw College (BMC) have employed a combination of experimental and numerical modeling approaches to investigate the properties of skyrmions in ferromagnetic/heavy metal (FM/HM) multilayered thin films where the DMI, exchange, and dipolar interactions as well as the magnetic anisotropy can be adjusted through the choice of materials, layer thicknesses, and multilayer repeats.


In specially designed [Co/Gd/Pt] multilayered films, we have discovered a spin memory effect that stems from the topological protection. We showed experimentally that antiferromagnetically coupled skyrmion pairs that are stable at room temperature evolve into complex in-plane spin textures as the temperature is lowered and then the skyrmions reform completely when the sample is warmed back up. Simulations demonstrate that the DMIs play a key role in this spin memory effect, and furthermore reveal that the topological charge is preserved throughout the spin rearrangement and recovery. Our results highlight a key aspect of topological protection - the preservation of the topological properties under continuous deformation - and provide a promising avenue for information encryption and recovery. This work on the topological spin memory effect was published as an Editor's Selection in Physical Review Materials, and we also filed a US patent application on spin memory encryption.

Our collaborative project has also led to development of a simple and reliable magnetic field treatment strategy for generating large numbers of magnetic skyrmions in multilayer thin films with interfacial DMIs at room temperature. We experimentally demonstrated that in [Pt/Co/Ir]3 multilayers the dendritic magnetic domains observed after an initial AC demagnetization evolve into magnetic bubble skyrmions after the application and subsequent removal of an in-plane magnetic field. Simulations show that the DMIs promote domain elongation during the field treatment that facilitates the skyrmion formation and applying the in-plane field at small angle away from the sample plane not only leads to improved skyrmion formation but also provides a means to select the skyrmion polarity. This field treatment scheme has been published as an invited contribution to a special issue of the Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials and will be useful for future investigations of skyrmion properties and applications. Our work on magnetic skyrmions in multilayer films also shows that the skyrmion size in zero magnetic field depends strongly on the repeat number of multilayers, and that skyrmion interactions that are overlooked in existing skyrmion theories are critical to explaining the observed size trend.

In addition to our work on skyrmions, at CSU we have used Brillouin light scattering (BLS) measurements to quantitatively measure the DMIs in multilayered magnetic/heavy metal thin films, explored the effects of DMIs on dynamic excitations in patterned nanostructures, developed new methods to extract the dispersion relations from micromagnetic simulations that provides a means to obtain rapid insight into spin wave behavior in complex situations where analytic approaches are difficult or impossible, developed tools that will improve skyrmion analysis by methods that involve the detection of stray magnetic fields, and we have  involved students in synergistic modeling projects.

The training of graduate and undergraduate students is an important component of our collaboration. Buchanan and Cheng have involved 9 graduate students (67% female) and 13 undergraduate students (92% female) in our collaborative NSF project. These students have received training on thin film deposition, lithography patterning, structural and magnetic characterization, BLS, synchrotron x-ray spectroscopy and imaging, and micromagnetic simulations, as well as, creative methodologies for conducting nanomagnetism and spintronics research. Co-advising students and holding regular joint group meetings between the two groups have enhanced the collaborations among a women's liberal arts college and a state research university. In particular, four BMC female undergraduate students conducted summer research at CSU.  The collaborations with other research institutions and national laboratories enhanced the productivity of existing infrastructure for research and education. Buchanan and Cheng also actively participate in outreach activities and have incorporated examples from this project involving skyrmions and spin waves in their teaching.
